content.description: Climb the arete past 2 bolts to the top.
content.protection: Mixed. Take a light rack. There are two directional bolts for pro on the wall. Bolted anchors.
content.location: Just left of the large chimney.

content.description: Spin Drift is the name Lloyd Ramsey gave this route.  It has a challenging start which requires some careful balancing.  Once past the overhang start, move right then up.  The crux is towards the top where a brief overhang exists with some good jugs.  There's an easier variation when you get to the crux by going right, although you will be swinging left a bit if you fall here.
content.protection: Top rope with two fixed bolts on a triangle-shaped rock.
content.location: This route is at The Beach. It's about 15 feet to the right of Hawaii Five-O.  There are two bolts at the top for anchoring.

content.description: This is an easy route.  It starts with small pockets and ledges.  The holds get bigger and sharper as you go.
content.location: Scarface is about 50 feet to the left of Body Surfin'.  It is just to the left of another cave/chimney and about 20 feet to the right of the gully used to reach the top for setting top-ropes.

content.description:
Climb the right corner to a chimney and a place to escape right onto the face and find the two bolt anchor.

This route is often wet and after a rain is a waterfall but When dry it has some fun stemming in the first 30' and protects well.
content.protection:
Light rack

To set a TR there is a single bolt on the slab above the anchor you can use to protect yourself to get down to the anchor over the edge.
content.location: To the right of Hawaii Five-O is a wide chimney with two obscure routes in the left and right corners.

content.description: Surprisingly solid rock with a variety of challenging moves that can pack quite a pump. Starts with a difficult move to reach the thin crack. Surmount the low overlap, then follows the crack using decent holds to a slopey crux.  After the delicate stance beneath the roof, climb out the steep crack and clip the anchor bolts (or top it out and belay).
content.protection: 0 TCU to 3.5" cam, nuts.  Bolted anchor.
content.location: Start right of Body Surfing and The Wave, just right of the wide chimney that splits The Beach.  Begin under a low overlap just right of the thin crack.

content.description: Starts with a good layback crack or optional stemming to a small ledge just underneath a narrow chimney. Squeeze into a narrow chimney with a heavily featured face beneath the anchors.  Plenty of holds are inside the chimney, but the juggy ones are a bit reachy.  Pull a small (& dirty) ledge to the face-bolted anchors.
content.protection: Top Rope. There are additional bolts on top of the cliff for additional protection (when clipping the face-bolted anchors). Take the Pool Hall Gulley to set a top rope.
content.location: Left side of the first (small) alcove you see approaching from Three Bears. There is another obvious route on the right side of this alcove.  This is appropriately named "Goofy Foot" since it's the left one. Look for the bolts with rap rings above the chimney - you can see them easily from the trail.

content.description: Lead up the face and wrap around the arete or just continue to the top of the face. Gear is kind of iffy due to the rock quality, however, there are a couple pieces that are pretty good. Big holds and good feet, overall an easy route.
content.protection: Light rack and a couple shoulder length slings. Use bolted anchor for Scarface.
content.location: The face around the arete to the right of Scarface.

content.description: This route is fun.  The start (a slabby ledge) and finish (a bit past vertical) are the toughest parts, but the holds are great and reminiscent of some of the granite boulders around Bishop, CA.  Just follow the big holds.
content.protection: Top rope or a rack with a wide range of gear.  Two bolts on top serve as an anchor.
content.location: The start is just left of the big chimney.  It begins with a ledge about 4 feet high that leads to a small right-facing dihedral.
